Award.AwardTitle: Pathogen mediated diversity and response to climate change
Award.AbstractNarration: Fungal pathogens are thought to control biodiversity of forest trees through selective mortality of competitively dominant species that would otherwise threaten less competitive species. Climate warming may thus increase the extent and severity of disease. As pathogens increasingly survive mild winters, reproductive rates increase and plant defenses suffer from drought and temperature stress. This research will assess the extent to which pathogens regulate tree seedling health, identify the fungi involved and their effects on tree growth and survival, and determine how those interactions are affected by the temperature changes predicted for mid-century. The study will determine how temperatures affect their hosts when temperatures increase, within the context of simultaneous competition from other tree species, using a warming experiment where tree seedlings are exposed to soil and air temperature increases of 3°C to 5°C in North Carolina and Massachusetts. Once seedlings emerge, germination, survival, disease symptoms, and growth will be monitored. Pathogenic fungi and oomycetes residing on both seeds and seedlings will be identified using a combination of culture and DNA sequence-based methods. The effects of warming on pathogen incidence, infection, and seedling demography will be assessed using models that account for the combination of temperature, pathogens, and competition with other trees. By incorporating different sources of data into the analyses, this research will provide insight into the basic biology of forest risk as the natural capacity of trees to defend themselves changes under a warmer climate. The proposed research will provide insight into spatial and temporal dynamics of plant pathogens in natural systems, and how these dynamics might change under a warmer climate. An improved understanding of the diversity and composition of populations of plant pathogens and environmental factors can both enhance current management practices and inform models of future tree distributions. Teaching, training, and learning will be an integral part of this study, as it will require the assistance of undergraduate and high school students as work-study assistants and summer research technicians. In addition, a survey-based data collection component will be initiated to engage K-12 and the interested public, which combines this diversity research with outreach activities supported by Duke Forest. The results of this study will be disseminated to high school students during the annual Duke Forest Research Days, and to the general public in a series of forest pathology hikes in the Duke Forest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fungal plant pathogens can influence the species composition of forests by attacking different tree species.  If a tree species that tends to dominate other tree species is attacked by a specific plant pathogen, then less competitive tree species can benefit.  There is a strong possibility that fungal pathogens are more likely to attack trees that are close to others that can harbor the fungus, primarily other trees of the same species. Using methods from ecology, mycology, plant pathology, and statistics we studied seedling establishment and fungal infection in ten Eastern North American tree species. Specifically, we examined how seedling survival at early stages of establishment was affected by the presence and proximity of adult trees of the same species and light availability in the forest.  We extensively sampled and sequenced seedling-associated fungi to study the pathogens affecting tree seedling health, determine their identity, and evaluate environmental characteristics that favor seedling infection. Finally, we used this information to infer their degree of host-preference, i.e., the tree species each fungus tends to attack.

We found that seedlings close to adults of the same species and at low light established at lower rates than those not exposed to these conditions. Analogous to the human microbiome project, we observed differences in the fungal species present in healthy seedling tissue compared to unhealthy seedlings.  Most of the pathogens identified were observed to infect more than one host species, however preference of infection in a tree species appeared to be modulated by environmental characteristics. For instance, pathogenic taxa were most often found on seedlings growing in deep shade and in warm locations. Furthermore, infection rates in high versus low light conditions differed among tree species, depending on physiological differences. Our results provide a first extensive inventory of the diversity and composition of the pathogens affecting seedlings from Eastern North American forests. It provides a first quantification of fungal pathogen impacts on forest regeneration, in particular under conditions of elevated temperature and changes on forest cover (and light availability). This information can enhance our ability to develop management practices to maintain forest health and inform models of future tree distributions.

This project provided educational opportunities for a) seedling identification b) seedling demographic studies and c) seedling disease symptomatology of Eastern North American trees to over 30 technicians and interns. It also trained technicians in laboratory methods for fungal isolation and identification. One female technician was fully trained on both field and laboratory methods required for this project, including high-throughput next generation sequencing. It also provided postdoctoral training, including mentoring in laboratory method development, manuscript and grant writing, data analysis and bioinformatics. Finally, methods and analyses have been integrated into undergraduate level classes taught at Duke University.
